articles.headline: Obama Pleads for Stricter Gun Laws and Faces Tough Questioning
articles.snippet: In an intense but civil town-hall-style event broadcast live on television, activists pressed President Obama to justify his gun-control efforts.
articles.abstract: In an intense but civil town-hall-style event broadcast live on television, activists pressed President Obama to justify his gun-control efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an intense but civil town-hall-style event broadcast live on television, gun rights activists repeatedly pressed President Obama on Thursday night to justify his gun control efforts, putting him on the defensive over an issue that has divided the nation’s capital and the presidential campaign trail.

articles.headline: For Stock Markets, January Is a Cloudy Crystal Ball
articles.snippet: The Stock Trader’s Almanac first posited that January markets can foretell the direction of the trading year, but statistics experts say causation is impossible to prove — or disprove.
articles.abstract: The Stock Trader’s Almanac first posited that January markets can foretell the direction of the trading year, but statistics experts say causation is impossible to prove — or disprove.
articles.lead_paragraph: As January goes, so goes the entire market year.

articles.headline: Can U.S. Remain an Island of Stability in the Global Economy?
articles.snippet: The economic mismatch between the United States and much of the rest of the world is not good for either party.
articles.abstract: The economic mismatch between the United States and much of the rest of the world is not good for either party.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese stock market is plummeting so fast that authorities there keep shutting it down. North Korea set off a bomb in a nuclear test. Two of the Middle East’s great powers, Saudi Arabia and Iran, are eyeing each other menacingly. In the European Union, political extremists are on the rise, migrants are pouring in and Britain may drop out (three phenomena that are not unrelated).

articles.headline: A New Economic Era for China Goes Off the Rails
articles.snippet: After its markets plunged last summer, and weeks after President Xi Jinping announced plans to avoid further disruptions, China again finds itself at the center of economic turmoil.
articles.abstract: After its markets plunged last summer, and weeks after President Xi Jinping announced plans to avoid further disruptions, China again finds itself at the center of economic turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When President Xi Jinping of China convened a group of top officials to discuss the economy last month, the highly publicized meeting was seen as a moment of triumph.

articles.headline: China’s Economic Turmoil Sends Ripples to Global Markets
articles.snippet: Some analysts and economists say they are becoming less optimistic that the United States will remain unscathed by China’s struggles.
articles.abstract: Some analysts and economists say they are becoming less optimistic that the United States will remain unscathed by China’s struggles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, the collapsing United States economy laid a dead hand on the rest of the world, a dubious role that was then assumed by Europe, whose sovereign debt crisis often pumped fear around the globe.

articles.headline: Obama’s Gun Initiative Seen as Having Limited Effect on Unlicensed Dealers
articles.snippet: “No one’s going to stop us” trading firearms through gun clubs and other markets, says one enthusiast who has long operated without a license, record-keeping or background checks.
articles.abstract: “No one’s going to stop us” trading firearms through gun clubs and other markets, says one enthusiast who has long operated without a license, record-keeping or background checks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jack Strahan has been a small-time trader of guns and gun parts for years, and he is not stopping now.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Campbell Labels Will Disclose G.M.O. Ingredients
articles.snippet: Campbell Soup breaks from its rival food companies to disclose the presence of genetically engineered ingredients in its products.
articles.abstract: Campbell Soup breaks from its rival food companies to disclose the presence of genetically engineered ingredients in its products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Breaking from its industry rivals, Campbell Soup will become the first major food company to begin disclosing the presence of genetically engineered ingredients like corn, soy and sugar beets in its products.

articles.headline: Robust Hiring in December Caps Solid Year for U.S. Jobs
articles.snippet: As the economy added 292,000 jobs last month, the question is whether overall growth will remain strong enough to keep hiring steady.
articles.abstract: As the economy added 292,000 jobs last month, the question is whether overall growth will remain strong enough to keep hiring steady.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time the American economy registered such a prolonged stretch of impressive job creation, Facebook didn’t exist and Beyoncé was still a member of Destiny’s Child.

articles.headline: Currency Devaluations by Asian Tigers Could Hinder Global Growth
articles.snippet: A number of foreign exchange specialists are worried that potential devaluations in South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan could hurt the global economy.
articles.abstract: A number of foreign exchange specialists are worried that potential devaluations in South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan could hurt the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s decision to push the value of its currency lower has opened a new front of worry for global investors: a potential wave of currency devaluations among the so-called Asian tigers — South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan.

articles.headline: How Should You Manage Your Money? And Keep It Short
articles.snippet: A comparison of lists giving financial advice shows that experts agree on the basic steps. So why do so few people follow the recipe?
articles.abstract: A comparison of lists giving financial advice shows that experts agree on the basic steps. So why do so few people follow the recipe?
articles.lead_paragraph: Editors’ note: Here’s one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

articles.headline: VW Refuses to Give American States Documents in Emissions Inquiries
articles.snippet: VW has refused to provide emails or other communications to attorneys general in the United States, citing German privacy laws, state officials say.
articles.abstract: VW has refused to provide emails or other communications to attorneys general in the United States, citing German privacy laws, state officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citing German privacy laws, Volkswagen has refused to provide emails or other communications among its executives to attorneys general in the United States, impeding American investigations into the company’s emissions-cheating scandal, according to officials in several states.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: 2015 Was a Great Year for Jobs. 2016 Will Have a Hard Time Matching It.
articles.snippet: A big question is whether the pace of job growth of the last two years can continue now that we are close to what economists consider full employment.
articles.abstract: A big question is whether the pace of job growth of the last two years can continue now that we are close to what economists consider full employment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The newest numbers on the state of the American job market are good news on almost every front and show that 2015 was a blockbuster year for jobs. That raises some important questions — and doubts — about what will happen in 2016.

articles.headline: Ratings Agencies Still Coming Up Short, Years After Crisis
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s annual report of credit ratings agencies finds that dubious practices persist long after the subprime meltdown.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s annual report of credit ratings agencies finds that dubious practices persist long after the subprime meltdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mistakes that led to the 2008 mortgage crisis can’t happen again, right?
